title: Managing conflict the next step
text:
In response, superannuation organisations now focus much more closely on how they manage conflicts, Borrelli says.

“You’re seeing organisations think about whether they are better off creating structural solutions that will enable the management of whatever persisting conflicts they have to be much easier and more transparent, and less inherently conflicted.

More conversations in super about independence

“There are a lot more conversations in super about independence in a number of areas, and considering outsourcing functions – in our case, in their trusteeship.”

Russell Mason, partner at Deloitte and national leader of the firm’s superannuation consulting and advisory services business, says independent trustees is one of the issues the government “still wants to address,” as is giving all Australians a “real choice” of super funds.

“There’s still a portion of the workforce that’s locked in to enterprise agreements – you join certain employers and you have no choice but to join the fund nominated by the enterprise agreement. That goes against the grain of what super should be, and I think we’ll see some subtle changes that will give people more choice,” Mason says.

“Independence” is a tricky issue, says Nick Callil, senior consultant and head of the retirement income practice at Willis Towers Watson.

“Whether the government mandates it or not, there is a shift to funds wanting to demonstrate that they have ‘independent’ trustees. Everyone is grappling with governance, but there is the problem that the people who have the skills that make them attractive as a trustee director have usually worked in the industry.

“But if we push too hard on the ‘independence’ aspect, then the most independent person is going to be someone who has never worked anywhere near the industry – and thus may not have the appropriate skill base. That can be a dilemma – we don’t want to prioritise independence over competence,” Callil says.

Level of fees

An obvious conflict area that the royal commission did not address – and which requires ongoing work – is the level of fees, charges and costs in the super industry, says independent governance expert Darren McShane, a former executive director of Hong Kong's mandatory pension regulator.

“That’s the classic conflict of interest area, where no matter what safeguards you have around it, there are always two diametrically opposed interests, being those getting the fees versus those paying them. The royal commission didn’t really touch on that, but there’s been a lot of activity from the regulator on that front,” McShane says.

Alex Dunnin, director of research and editorial at financial services research firm Rainmaker Group, says fees are just one aspect of the “efficiency issues” that dog the system – and which are at least as detrimental as conflicts of interest. “Australians pay about $32 billion a year in super fund fees, so while everyone focuses on conflicts, the system is just too expensive. It’s great that annual fees have reduced to a 1 per cent benchmark, but given so few funds beat their asset class benchmarks you have to wonder how they can justify charging even 1 per cent,” Dunnin says.

Conflicts will always exist, he says, but they are “being better managed,” and reducing. “As long as we have people paid or remunerated in any way from the funds they recommend, advise on or help manage, there will be conflicts. But the point is that conflicts are being pushed out. We need to fix the problem of conflicts of interest, but we also have to fix the problem of the free-riders and rent-seekers that exist in superannuation.”

Deloitte’s Mason says there are “still too many super funds” – there are about 100 on offer in the Australian marketplace – and on efficiency grounds, the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority (APRA) will “get much more serious in the near future” on encouraging mergers. “APRA won’t do that by saying to funds directly, ‘You need to merge,’ but it will set tests and minimum criteria for them to meet,” Mason says.

The mergers issue

“Then they’ll tell the fund, ‘You’re not meeting these standards, and if you continue not to meet these standards, we will have to rethink your holding an APRA licence and being able to operate your fund.’ So I think we will see mergers continue for some time – surprisingly, led by the bigger funds, not the smaller funds, who probably should be having those discussions more pressingly.”

Ultimately, Mason sees a small number of very large super funds – about 10 – and then about 20–30 smaller to mid-sized funds serving specific industries, niche players. “There is a place for both. I don’t agree necessarily with the school of thought that says, ‘Unless you’re a $30 billion fund you won’t survive – I think there are some mid-sized funds that will survive because they have a loyal membership and they’re serving a niche industry; and perhaps they’re able to provide some services and insurance cover that more generalist funds can’t provide,” he says.

Dunnin also sees mega-funds emerging. “We can be reasonably certain that the leading 10-to-15 funds will become really dominant. Some of these organisations will become enormous, and become fundamentally different beasts – mega-investors on a scale we have not seen in Australia. They will have staggeringly large amounts of capital to invest, and they will become massive financial institutions, and global players.''

The size of the system is “creating its own problems,” he says. At present, the Australian superannuation pool holds $2.8 trillion, or 145 per cent of Australia's GDP.

As the system grows, Rainmaker projects it to reach about $8 trillion by 2040. “That’s got to be managed and we haven’t even begun to think about the ramifications of that. But it’s a great problem to have – superannuation is a national treasure, and it’s going to be an export opportunity for us. We have to remember that many other countries would die to be in our position,” he says.
description: Efficiency issues, such as high fees and under-performance, are prevalent.
